body: Nevermind @nlu90 I found it: #2112
I'm concerned something is not right with CI. This test fails locally and on recent unmerged PRs (#2111), but not on other PRs merges since #2103
@billonahill  any comments or shipit?
Yes, I will review. Apologies, a snafu in my email filters caused me to miss all github emails for 2 days...

One of the challenges with this is that Twitter's CI environment can't access the public internet. This can be done though by deploying a custom proxy rule. The challenge though is that the proxy must point to a valid URI path that's not a file. These files are examples of where we want to proxy:

https://github.com/google/protobuf/archive/v3.3.0.tar.gz
https://github.com/google/glog/archive/v0.3.5.tar.gz

But paths like `https://github.com/google/protobuf/archive/`are invalid and return 404s. @kramasamy do you know of another location where these can be pulled that actually mirrors a directory structure? Even path's like `https://github.com/google/protobuf/tree/v3.3.0` can be proxied, but the artifacts don't live below that path anywhere.

Doing a sed to change to an internal URL as part of the build process is
fine, we do that elsewhere already. What we don't want to do is have to
manually pull new tags. I suspect we can make this work with Mark's
suggested approach.

@billonahill - the reason why mirror will not work is because the repo that you pulling down streamlio/bazel_rules_pex will in turn pull remote repositories - under the hood in bazel. This makes it hard to do 'twitterify' style script.
@srkukarni Agree. I am on PTO and will find time to do so. Also, exclamation topology is throttled now so I will try word count one instead.
@kramasamy right, that won't work. Could the pex code be published as a versioned tar? That way it could be downloaded and extracted instead.

@kramasamy we have the ability to upload artifacts to our internal repository and change WORKSPACE to point to them at build time. Could you submit a patch to migrate just one cpp library to use the http approach, maybe glog? We can then verify that patch internally before migrating the rest of them.
üëç

@billonahill - good idea. After some investigation, I found out that there is no need to use bazel git_repository for fetching the pex rules. In fact bazel discourages it. Instead, we can use http_archive to fetch the tar ball for even rules - something like this

```
pex_rules_version = "0.3.8"
pex_rules_url_prefix = "https://github.com/streamlio/bazel_rules_pex/archive/"
pex_rules_url = pex_rules_url_prefix + pex_rules_version + ".tar.gz"
pex_rules_sha256 = "071b75d24611910b9fd250366688581c813b62680267760b23389912714b6e72"

# for pex rules
http_archive(
  name = "io_bazel_rules_pex",
  url = pex_rules_url,
  strip_prefix = "bazel_rules_pex-" + pex_rules_version,
  sha256 = pex_rules_sha256,
)

load("@io_bazel_rules_pex//pex:pex_rules.bzl", "pex_repositories")
pex_repositories()
```
Fixed the branch with these changes, please take a look at it - whether it makes it easy.
@ashvina any updates to Bill's comments?
On testing on local mac and a linux based local mode in gcloud, i found 7-8% perf regression due to this change. Hence closing this pr.

@nlu90 Just looked a little closely at the reconnect interval. Its currently set at 1 second. Which basically means that if we fail for 30 seconds we kill the stmgr. I believe this is too aggressive. Maybe increase the max reconnect attempts from 30 to 300?

Basically, we need the following when we submit a topology 

[INFO]: Using config file under /Users/karthikz/.heron/conf/local
[INFO]: Launching topology: 'etc'
[INFO]: Uploading topology jar to <whatever the uploader is>
[INFO]: Scheduling topology in <whatever the scheduler is>
[INFO]: Successfully launched topology 'etc'
[INFO]: Elapsed time: 2.405s.

Providing minimal information as each step is complete - so that user knows at a high level what is the current step, if that step is successful and the total time it took to complete. We print Elapsed time for all the commands just - to give an idea for the user - similar to what bazel does.

@kramasamy 
The config file looks like stuff in verbose mode. When submitting regularly, I really don't look at the config file.
I agree that we need to add some more comments in Uploading to and scheduling in. I can add those in later prs.
The Elapsed time comparison to bazel is slightly is not appropriate imo. bazel is a compilation tool which values how much time it spent while compiling. We are just submitting the job, submission time is something that's not really a highlight.

Elapsed time is needed since the jobs are varying size, operating over different schedulers and different networks. I would feel comfortable keeping it. In fact it was added based on feedback from teams. On the config file, if you have multiple clusters and different config paths being provided, it is good to display so that you have an idea which config file is being used - since there are typically multiple of them.
+1. We need this for every release.
@srkukarni Updated.  Thanks for this suggestion
looks good!

* Can we generate javadocs for the entire codebase?
I plan to do that in the future.

* How are javadocs currently being generated for the website?
Currently a release script is run separately which generates googles docs outside the build process.

Also when would you expect to trigger this? As part of CI and the website build, or just some other time?
As part of CI process , the website script should be able to gather the artifacts and publish them as needed.
We should not have 2 different ways to generate javadocs. Can you change this patch to replace the existing approach with this one?

The website docs[1] state:

> Java 8 is required by Bazel but Heron does not use Java 8 features; Heron topologies can be written in Java 7 or above and all Heron jars are compatible with Java 7.

Would you please update that to say that Heron requires java 8.

1 - https://twitter.github.io/heron/docs/developers/compiling/compiling/
@billonahill update the docs in the repo

The intention, from both of our perspectivces, is absolutely to have a single Javadoc generation process (which could also be utilized by the website build process) and not multiple. I'll discuss further with him and see if there's a workable approach that can be included with this PR.

One broad comment. This change seems to be making a single connectors and putting spouts/sinks in there. Instead would a second level differentiation help? I.e. connectors/spouts, connections/sinks?

We could have a second level that groups things by type connectors/pulsar, connectors/jdbc, etc... The source (spout) and sink (bolt) would be together in the second level in case they need to share common code. This is what other projects do as well. Thoughts?

pretty sure we need some time to make Python3 default inside twtr

@objmagic Note that this change does not force python3. Rather it moves away from using apis that are python2 only to apis that are existing in both python2 and python3. This way we can run Heron on both python2(which is what Twitter's environment is) as well as python3.
ok sounds good

This PR has been refactored. Ping @srkukarni @nlu90 @kramasamy for review
TBR 4:30PM.

Assume [`stmgr A` -> `out queue(destination stmgr B)`] -> [`in queue` -> `stmgr B`]. The `out queue(destination stmgr B)` size in stmgr A may indidate the processing ability of stmgr B. A simple idea is sending out tuples according to `out queue(destination stmgr B)` size.
This PR has been refactored. Ping @srkukarni @nlu90 @kramasamy for review
@tomncooper  - please send a PR for this fix.
@huijunw I once mentioned this idea with @maosongfu and @ttim but they think (and I was convinced) that using `in queue` size is more accurate.

Some places we are using bookkeeper and come places we are using dlog should we standardize on one in the code base for consistency?

If I look at the code, there are already parameters controlling the size of HeronTupleSet(which is actually just a collection of HeronDataTuple). The issue arises when one HeronDataTuple is so large that it blows away all these limits.
IMO the way to solve this would be some sort of setting inside the instance that controls what is the largest size of HeronDataTuple allowed. And throw an error to the user if the user's emit is larger than that. Thoughts?
agree @srkukarni . Throwing an error lets user know the tuple is too large.

@kramasamy @jrcrawfo This page has already been added to the docs:

https://twitter.github.io/heron/docs/operators/deployment/schedulers/kubernetes/
https://github.com/twitter/heron/blob/master/website/content/docs/operators/deployment/schedulers/kubernetes.md

I'd recommend closing this PR.
The question is whether this should be made configurable? And if so, how. Might be something worthwhile in the API.
@srkukarni see #2224 for a fix. We are not making it configurable. Just check if a single data tuple could be larger than the size limit of a set of data tuple.
Good catch. The solution is the other way around, numbers need not be specified as strings. I am testing the fix locally. Will create a PR soon.

what is the motivation to separate python from the current directory structure?
We are trying to segregate the external client python package from the internal python code and adopting a flat directory structure so import statements become more straightforward.
do we plan to refactor the present src code to be compatible with both python 2 and python 3?

One issue with this pr is that it is making system components(like executor) depend on heronpy which is not what we want to do. I don't think thats a good idea. One issue that we need to address in this pr is to make sure that heron/common does not depend on heronpy.

Yes. One step at a time :)
First we need to make sure that heron compiles both in python2 and python3. Currently the sticking points for this are a) bazel needs to be upgraded to 0.5.4 and b) pex needs to be upgraded in place
Cool. Looks like a long journey. :)

My thoughts:

For every config we need to have single source of truth of what type the config is so as to be consistent across the whole project.  I also don't think we should manually convert the configs to strings.  If we need to do so across languages for compatibility, we can always create a layer of converting certain configs to strings and converting them back to the correct types where appropriate

One potential reason is that our zk library is too old and contains many bugs which have since been solved. Here is the change to update that to latest stable version
https://github.com/twitter/heron/pull/2245
@srkukarni Thanks for the review.  I have addressed your comment

Any updates on this?  
Protobuf 3 support would be nice to have. We have a few protobufs that are written in the proto 3 syntax which we would like to use with Heron.
@rohanag12 This is slated for the 0.15.3 release.
BTW any users of Heron can use proto2 or proto3. This ticket is just for the internal implementation of certain Heron components and does not have any ramifications from user perspective.
a related mailing list thread https://groups.google.com/forum/#!searchin/protobuf/reuse$20memory%7Csort:relevance/protobuf/TSzsFu3DPmQ/9BjFXpkdAc0J
Thats interesting obs. So ByteSize is probably more related to wire format size and SpaceUsed is related to actual in memory repr. In that case, shouldn't you use SpaceUsed? But isn;t that very slow?
ping @ashvina @maosongfu for review
@srkukarni It seems that we have no choice but to use `SpaceUsed` here. We can do some benchmark here to measure its performance.
@srkukarni I have address your comments
If the performance is a concern, I would suggest the old method: put it in mempool and run a garage collection against mempool to remove large tuples every 1 min.
